in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: live virtual lecture and asynchronous self-studying
n/a
Classes met virtually MWF and for occasionally on T/Th for assessments. On non-assessment days, T/Th were self learning.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: i learned so much spanish in just 13 weeks. i am surprised and glad. i got so much better at speaking in Spanish. so much of my knowledge of Spanish has been polished up. craig is a very welcoming professor!
I began to learn the Spanish language.

Through this class, I developed a foundation in Spanish grammar and vocabulary. Although I am far from fluent, there is already a decent amount of Spanish I can read and understand, which really surprised me.
A good understanding of beginner spanish, how to have discussions, Spanish culture, and some Latin American culture.
I learnt a great deal of Spanish, starting with absolutely no prior knowledge in the language.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: i personally feel like i didn't learn anything new in class ever. it was just learning on our own through Supersite, then having the information regurgitated in class. i feel like having office hours instead of synchronous classes could be helpful for students with questions.
The low teacher-student ratio made practicing the language engaging and effective.

Strengths: I was by far the most engaged with Spanish this semester, compared to my other class (humanities lectures and seminars). The classes and homework were always engaging. Craig was also a fantastic instructor, and I truly appreciated his encouragement and thoughtfulness in class. 

Weakness: I know this is a 1.5-credit class, but at times the workload verged on being unmanageable for me. Perhaps instructors could consider making daily homework due the day that class meets (although I know there are downsides to this too). One other stressful thing for me was having no Spanish background at all, so I often felt behind other students that had that Spanish background.
The professor and the course structure is a strength. It's difficult to compare this to an in person class, but I feel it was more challenging to apply the spanish in class.

Prof. Osterbrock is a great teacher. I appreciated that he gave us opportunities to speak without breaking the class into breakout rooms. He was incredibly helpful at office hours, and very understanding of students' circumstances.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: all classes can all be asynchronous because we learn information on our own, and having it re-taught to us again in synchronous class wasn't too useful
In person instruction would definitely have been more engaging.

The class, I think by nature of being a language class, was extremely engaging even in the virtual format. We were expected to speak and answer questions throughout class, so my engagement was always high in class.
The supersite website was very helpful. Also, having to meet with students on zoom outside of class for projects was nice and made the class feel more realistic.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: yes! span 110 was so fun and intersting
Yes.

If anyone wants to learn Spanish, this class will definitely give you the basic foundations for the language! As someone who tried previously to self-study Spanish, I think the classroom format is far better for building the basics for future study. I have been surprised that I can read / mostly understand Spanish posts I see on social media, which perhaps gives you a sense of the amount of learning we fit into one semester.
Yes, if you want to learn Spanish.
